------_=_NextPart_001_01C0CD02.397B1450
Content-Type: text/plain;

In my mind the intent is to get better at testing.  Start by writing a test
for everything that can break.  If these two tests work, then you'll be able
to safely conclude a that a third test will work with out writing it.
 
Chris Johnson
Omni Resources.

-----Original Message-----
From: Houston, Greg (ISSAtlanta) [mailto:ghouston@...]
Sent: Tuesday, April 24, 2001 3:56 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Is coverage important? RE: Test Coverage Analysis To ol
For Junit


Is coverage really that important?  The directive is to "Test everything
that could possibly break", not "Test everything".
 
Unit Tests give you great benefits in productivity and quality.  I have
worked on XP teams that measured both quality and productivity.  Unit
Testing and XP does improve both!  However, there comes a point where more
Unit Tests only marginally increases quality while not increasing
productivity (even negatively impacting productivity).  Developers should
question the value of creating more Unit Tests.  If you are not careful, you
can get into a "Test everything" mode and kill productivity.
 
Since Coverage metrics can lead the team to focus on "Test Everything", it
isn't a great measurement.  Instead, focus on "things that could break" and
you will continue to gain both increased productivity and quality.   Only
use Coverage tools to reveal something that could break.  Using coverage as
a metric is a poor practice.  I suggest using quality metrics instead (i.e.
number of Unit Tests and number of passing Functional Tests)
 
- Greg Houston
www.ISS.net <http://www.ISS.net> 
 
 
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Eugene Siu [mailto:esiu@...]
Sent: Tuesday, April 24, 2001 4:34 PM
To: 'Michael Silverstein '; 'junit@yahoogroups.com '
Subject: RE: [junit] RE: Test Coverage Analysis Tool For Junit



How about JTest?  It works well with Junit. 

-----Original Message----- 
From: Michael Silverstein 
To: junit@yahoogroups.com 
Sent: 4/24/2001 7:02 AM 
Subject: [junit] RE: Test Coverage Analysis Tool For Junit 

The newest version of Test Mentor adds method coverage metrics and the 
ability to run JUnit tests. 

More info about Test Mentor and JUnit at: 
http://www.javatesting.com/documentation/stmjunit.pdf
<http://www.javatesting.com/documentation/stmjunit.pdf>
